entry.title: Silence remembers Tunisia attack dead

entry.title: Britain, Tunisia honor 38 victims of beach resort attack
entry.summary:
People observe the minute silence for the victims of the shooting in Tunisia last week, at the All England Lawn Tennis Championships in Wimbledon, London, Friday July 3, 2015.

Fans and staff at Wimbledon observed a minute's silence for the victims of last Friday's attack in Tunisia, in which 30 Britons were killed in a shooting rampage at a beach resort in Sousse.

entry.title: Britain, Tunisia honor 38 victims of beach resort attack
entry.summary: Flags have been lowered to half-staff at Buckingham Palace and U.K. government buildings as Britain and Tunisia honor the 38 victims of an Islamic extremist's rampage at a Tunisian beach resort.

entry.title: Britain falls silent to remember 30 killed in Tunisian gun attack
entry.summary:
A Union flag flies at half-mast on Buckingham Palace in London, to mark an official day of mourning a week since the deadly Tunisia beach attack.

The coffin of Denis Thwaites is carried from an RAF C-17, which repatriated the bodies of eight British nationals killed in the Tunisia terror attack, at RAF Brize Norton near Oxford.

entry.title: Tunisia beach hotel attack: 12 arrested in connection with massacre

entry.summary: Karl Turner, the MP for East Hull, tweeted: "So sorry Claire Windass from Hull was killed in Tunisia terrorist attack. My thoughts with family & friends. RIP."

entry.title: Tunisia attack: Bodies of all but one of the British victims identified, according to Government
entry.summary: "I can confirm that the number of Britons killed in the Tunisia terrorist attack who have been positively identified has now reached 29," Mr Hammond said.

entry.title: Tunisia gunman Saif Rezgui trained in Libya at same time as Bardo museum killers
entry.summary:
Tunis: The Tunisian gunman who carried out a deadly attack on a hotel last Friday trained in a jihadist camp in Libya last year, Tunisia's government said on Tuesday.

Tunisia's Health Ministry said on Tuesday it had so far identified 33 bodies from Friday's violence, including 25 British, three Irish, one Belgian, two German, a Russian citizen and a Portuguese national.

Tunisia expects to lose at least $670 million this year, or about a quarter of its estimated annual tourism earnings, following last Friday's attack.

entry.title: Tunisia beach gunman trained in Libya with museum attackers: Official
entry.summary:
The revelation confirms repeated fears that the strong presence of the Islamic State group in neighbouring Libya has become a direct threat to Tunisia, the only democracy to emerge from the Arab Spring uprisings.

Increasingly, however, they have stayed in Libya before returning to carry out attacks in Tunisia.

Tunisia's most well-known Islamic radical Seifallah Ben Hassine, fled to Libya in 2013 taking many supporters with him into exile.

entry.summary: Sousse: At a makeshift memorial on the site of last Friday's deadly attack, a steady stream of tourists and locals gathered to lay flowers and notes to remember the victims of Tunisia's worst ever terror attack.

SBIBA, Tunisia, May 17 (Reuters) - One of the young men was a high school literature student who helped his father tend the family olive trees in their isolated farming community near the Algerian border.

But according to Tunisia's interior ministry, they both spent time in militant camps in Libya late last year before returning to Tunisia, their ideologies fine-tuned and basic military training completed.

It was a time of flux in Tunisia.

More than 20 residents of Sbiba, including students and professionals, have left to fight for militant groups outside Tunisia, said Kechini.

On March 18, they came together to attack Tunisia's Bardo Museum, shooting foreign tourists as they filed off buses outside the museum, and then taking more tourists hostage inside.

British police are in Tunisia helping in the process of formally identifying victims.

Tour companies have helped thousands of tourists leave Tunisia since Friday's attack on a country that relies heavily on tourism for jobs and foreign currency revenues.

entry.title: The Latest: Queen Elizabeth II shocked about Tunisia attack

Police officers patrol on the beach of Sousse, Tunisia, Sunday, June 28, 2015.

Tunisia's top security official says 1,000 extra police are being deployed at tourist sites and beaches in the North African nation after Friday's attack.

A Tunisian police officer guards the beach area in front of the attacked Imperial Marhaba Hotel in Sousse, Tunisia, Sunday, June 28, 2015.

Queen Elizabeth II says the attack on a beach resort in Tunisia has left her and her husband, Prince Philip, shocked.

entry.title: European tour operators evacuate thousands from Tunisia after attack
entry.summary:
SOUSSE, Tunisia Tour companies were evacuating thousands of foreign holidaymakers from Tunisia on Saturday, a day after a gunman killed 39 people at a beach hotel in an attack claimed by Islamic State.

Tour operators Thomson and First Choice, which are owned by German travel group TUI, said they had about 6,400 customers across Tunisia at the time of the attack, including several of the people killed and injured.

entry.title: Terror on the beach: Tourists recount Tunisia attack horrors
entry.summary: No one grasped what was happening at first in what became Tunisia's worst terrorist attack.

entry.title: Dozens killed in attacks in Tunisia, Kuwait and France
entry.summary:
Since overthrowing its secular dictator in 2011, Tunisia has been plagued by terrorist attacks, although only recently have they targeted the tourism sector, which makes up nearly 15 percent of GDP.

The attacks are also a blow to Tunisia's image as a stable, democratic nation emerging from its revolution in 2011, said Jonathan Hill, a professor of Defense Studies at King's College in London.

entry.title: Dozens killed in attacks in Tunisia, Kuwait and France
entry.summary: A pool of blood is seen on the ground near the area where a terrorist attack took place in the coastal town of Sousse, Tunisia, Friday June 26, 2015.

entry.title: Dozens killed in attacks in Tunisia, Kuwait and France
entry.summary: In Britain, police said they were tightening security at major events after the attacks in France, Kuwait and Tunisia, including for the weekend events of Armed Forces Day and the Pride London gay and lesbian festival.

entry.title: The Latest: US condemns attacks in France, Kuwait, Tunisia
entry.summary:
White House Press Secretary Josh Earnest says "the United States condemns in the strongest terms the terrorist attacks in France, Kuwait and Tunisia today."

The international police agency Interpol is offering its investigative help to Tunisia, France, Kuwait and Somalia after separate attacks that have killed more than 80 people.

The French attack Friday came on the same day as a gunman mowed down scores of tourists on a beach in Tunisia and a suicide bomber killed over two dozen worshippers at a Shiite mosque in Kuwait.

entry.title: Women's miniskirt protest fails to catch on in Tunisia
entry.summary: TUNIS, Tunisia- Only a handful of women have answered a call by a Tunisian rights' group to protest the repression of women in the Muslim world by demonstrating in miniskirts.

entry.summary:

Lilia Kammoun, a teacher at the protest, said Tunisia is regressing.

entry.title: Tunisia PM: Destroying Migrant Boats Won't Stop Europe Flow
entry.summary: Tunisia's prime minister says a European Union proposal to destroy boats used by smugglers to ferry migrants to Europe from Libya probably won't work and is risky because it is similar to military intervention.

entry.summary: He said intervention to destroy the rickety boats before they cross the Mediterranean "is considered by Tunisia as almost a military intervention."

entry.title: Mystery surrounds movements of Italy's Tunisia Bardo suspect

Alfano also suggested that independent of Tunisia's investigations, Italian intelligence had also begun tracking Touil as a potential suspect.

The spokesman of Tunisia's Interior Ministry, Mohammed Ali Aroui, would not comment on Touil's whereabouts the day of the attack but said he was certain about his identity.

entry.title: Mystery surrounds movements of Italy's Tunisia Bardo suspect
entry.summary:

At the same time, Tunisia supplies the largest contingent of foreign fighters to extremist group Islamic State, according to the Tunisian government.

Before the revolution that ousted President Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali in 2011, Tunisia's religious conservatives mostly kept out of politics.

In May 2013, Tunisia's then Islamist-led government banned Ansar al-Sharia, forcing its leadership and members underground.

entry.title: US delivers Humvees, patrol boat to Tunisia
entry.summary: The United States announced on Thursday the delivery of 52 Humvee military vehicles and a patrol boat to help Tunisia counter jihadist violence and ward off the insecurity of neighbouring Libya.

entry.title: Tunisia steps up security at Jewish pilgrimage to Ghriba
entry.summary:
Tunisian Jew Chantal Dabi lights a candle at the Ghriba synagogue in Djerba, south Tunisia, Wednesday, May 6, 2015.

Pilgrims arrived for the pilgrimage at Tunisia's Ghriba synagogue, the oldest in Africa.

entry.title: Tunisia steps up security at Jewish pilgrimage
entry.summary: Tunisia says it has heightened security for the Jewish pilgrimage to the age-old Ghriba synagogue after the Bardo museum attack in Tunis that left 22 people dead, mostly foreign tourists.

entry.title: Tunisia steps up security at Jewish pilgrimage
Tunisia says Jewish pilgrims safe, after Israel warning
entry.summary:
Tunisia said Sunday security measures have already been taken to protect Jewish pilgrims at a religious festival next week on the island of Djerba, after Israel warned of "concrete threats".

"Tunisia is a safe country and Djerba too is a safe city. Visitors from the world over are welcome," Gharsalli said.

Tunisian Jews now number around 1,500, compared with an estimated 100,000 when Tunisia gained independence in 1956.

But Gharsalli insisted that Tunisia can protect visitors "better than any other country".

entry.title: Tunisia's neglected youth find their voice in hip hop, rap
entry.summary: Police under the country's former dictator were reviled in Tunisia as the oppressive arm of a corrupt system - a role activists and urban youth say they continue to play in poorer neighborhoods.

entry.title: Tunisia's neglected youth find their voice in hip hop, rap
entry.summary: TUNIS, Tunisia (AP) - On the roof of a concrete building in an impoverished Tunis neighborhood, hip hop beats pound out from a PC hooked up to cheap speakers.

entry.title: Tunisia's neglected youth find their voice in hip hop, rap
entry.summary:
Tunisian youth are getting out their message of rage about life on the fringes in post-revolution Tunisia through a perhaps surprising channel: hip hop.

Since overthrowing its long-ruling dictator in 2011, Tunisia has had a string of elections and is being hailed as "the success story" of the region.

Despite spearheading the revolution, Tunisia's youth are still feeling sidelined, and one of the few ways they are getting their voices heard is through rap - shouting to anyone who will listen that all is not well in Tunisia.

Tunisia's parliamentary elections last fall saw reasonably high voting rates.

entry.title: Tunisia military says 10 extremists killed in fighting
entry.summary: TUNIS,Tunisia (AP) - Tunisia's defense ministry says 10 militants have been killed in fighting along the border with Algeria.

entry.title: Tunisia finds weapons, arrests jihadist with explosive belt
entry.summary: Tunisia has launched a campaign against hardline Islamist groups who emerged after a 2011 uprising against autocrat Zine El-Abidine Ben Ali that put the North African country on track to democracy.

entry.title: Almost 180 migrants rescued off Tunisia
entry.summary:
Tunisia's coastguard and navy Monday rescued almost 180 African migrants from two boats which broke down as they headed from Libya to Italy, the Red Crescent and an AFP correspondent said.

The Red Crescent said the migrants -- 94 on one boat and 84 on the other -- sent out a distress call from off the coast of southeast Tunisia as they headed for the Italian island of Lampedusa.

entry.title: U.S. to triple military aid to Tunisia
entry.summary:
The U.S. government aimed to provide Tunisia with more equipment, weapons and technical support, U.S. deputy secretary of state Antony Blinken said.

Since a 2011 uprising that toppled Zine El-Abidine Ben Ali, Tunisia has, in contrast to much of North Africa and the Middle East, experienced a comparatively trouble-free transition toward democracy.

entry.title: After Bardo attack, Tunisia treads line between security and freedoms
entry.summary: But last month's attack is testing Tunisia's tricky balance between security and the new liberties since the revolt, which ousted long-running autocrat Zine El-Abidine Ben Ali.

entry.title: 5th Tunisian soldier dies from wounds after ambush as 13 suspects are arrested
entry.summary: TUNIS, Tunisia - Tunisia's defense spokesman said a fifth soldier has died from wounds suffered in an ambush Tuesday that also wounded eight people.

entry.title: 5th Tunisia soldier dies of wounds after ambush

entry.summary:
Four years after its revolt, Tunisia is unlikely to slide back to the days of Ben Ali's oppressive state.

"Yes, Tunisia has been hit hard, but we can't let that hurt our rights and freedoms."

Since its transition to democracy, Tunisia has been praised by the West as a symbol of democratic hope for a region where other "Arab Spring" nations are caught up in division, intolerance and outright war.

"All these declarations are quite disturbing," Amna Guellali director of the Human Rights Watch Tunisia.

entry.title: Militant ambush kills 2 soldiers in Tunisia near border
entry.summary: TUNIS, Tunisia (AP) - Tunisia's army spokesman says an ambush by extremists in a mountainous region near the Algerian border has killed two soldiers and wounded three others.

entry.title: Tunisia trial of deadly ambush suspects adjourned
entry.summary:
The trial of 77 people in Tunisia charged with involvement in a jihadist attack that killed eight soldiers was adjourned Monday after the defence asked for more time to prepare.

If convicted, they could be sentenced to death, despite Tunisia no longer carrying out capital punishment.

Since the January 2011 revolution, Tunisia has experienced jihadist violence that has killed dozens of members of the security forces.

Last year some six million tourists came to Tunisia, generating around $2 billion in revenues.

The Bardo assault shocked Tunisia, which had mostly managed to escape the upheaval of other "Arab Spring" countries four years after its own revolt toppled autocrat Ben Ali.

entry.summary: Authorities have arrested several people in the attack, the worst in Tunisia in 13 years, and are still hunting for the suspected mastermind.

entry.summary: Tunisia has been hailed as a model for compromise politics between secular and Islamist politicians, approving a progressive new constitution and holding presidential and parliamentary elections last year.

entry.title: Tunisia: Museum hit by terrorist attack delays reopening

entry.summary: TUNIS, Tunisia - The curator of the Tunisian museum targeted by a terrorist attack announced Tuesday it is postponing its reopening, for logistical and security reasons.

entry.title: Security concerns delay reopening of Tunisia national museum
entry.summary: Tunisia's national museum on Tuesday delayed a planned reopening after last week's attack on foreign tourists due to security concerns, its head of communications Hanene Srarfi told AFP.

entry.title: In Tunisia's tourist heartland, anxious wait after attack
entry.summary:
YASMIN HAMMAMET, Tunisia (Reuters) - The European visitors strolling Tunisia's Hammamet resort are an encouraging sign for a government determined to minimize the fallout of last week's shooting of 20 tourists in the nearby capital.

Japanese, Spanish, Italian and Colombian tourists were among the victims when at least two gunmen opened fire on their buses as they arrived at the Tunis Bardo Museum, which houses some of the Roman artifacts that are one of Tunisia's major draws.

entry.title: Tunisia releases video of attackers entering Bardo museum

entry.title: Known to Police, Tunisia Attackers Had Trained in Libya
entry.summary:
"The state has been considerably weakened by its porous borders between Libya and Tunisia," he told reporters.

"As long as Libya stays as it is now, our country will still be threatened by these phenomena. So we have to look for a resolution in Libya," said Rachid Ghannouchi, the leader of Tunisia's powerful moderate Islamist Ennahda party.

Speaking Friday at the opening of the latest round of peace talks between Libya's rival parliaments, UN envoy Bernardino Leon said the bombing in Tunisia added even more urgency to efforts to reconcile Libya's warring factions.

entry.title: Known to police, Tunisia attackers had trained in Libya

"Over the coming weeks, the main challenge for Tunisia's political establishment is to avoid the temptation to revert to the old norm of authoritarian governance, which in the past has proved incapable of maintaining long-term stability," says Ayari.

entry.title: Polish woman hurt in Tunisia attack was readying for death

entry.summary: WARSAW, Poland - A Polish woman who was among the first injured in the Tunisia museum thought she was dying from her wounds.

entry.title: EU leaders pledge security cooperation, aid for Tunisia
Terror attack in Tunisia a fresh blow to tourism industry
entry.summary:
The terror attack in Tunisia that killed 21 people is a fresh blow to the North African nation's tourism industry, which has been struggling since the country's revolution of 2011.

Some of those posting "Je Suis Bardo" on social media pledged to visit Tunisia this summer.

"It's important to just show that we're not afraid to be here in Tunisia," said Nicole Calande, 20, of San Jose, California.

Another student, Maile Munro, 21, from Seattle, said when Tunisians share their fear that tourists will stay away, she wants to tell them, "We know that Tunisia is more than this."

Tunisia's president also urged tourists to keep visiting, insisting that security measures are being taken.

Tourism to Tunisia plunged after the revolution in 2011 led to the overthrow of an authoritarian president and augured the so-called Arab Spring.

entry.title: Plans for leisurely visit in Tunisia turn to horror
entry.summary: Rubio, who is pregnant, was uninjured and told Tunisia's health minister at a hospital maternity ward that tests showed that the baby girl on the way was OK.

entry.title: Plans for leisurely visit in Tunisia turn to horror
entry.summary: TUNIS, Tunisia (AP) - Around lunchtime, the crackle of gunfire broke the leisurely calm of a visit to one of Tunisia's best-known museums: Two attackers went on a rampage targeting tourists.

entry.title: Plans for leisurely visit in Tunisia turn to horror
Obama pledges security cooperation after Tunisia attack
entry.summary:
President Barack Obama is pledging close counterterrorism cooperation with Tunisia in the wake of an attack that killed 21 people at a museum in Tunis.

Obama also commended Tunisians for their response and called Tunisia's democracy a "powerful example" for the region.

The White House says Obama offered to keep providing assistance to Tunisia as the investigation proceeds.

entry.title: Islamic State group claims deadly attack on Tunis museum
entry.summary: The Islamic State jihadist group claimed responsibility Thursday for an attack on foreign tourists at Tunisia's national museum that killed 21 people, as the security forces swooped on suspects.

entry.title: 17 foreign tourists killed in Tunisia were cruise passengers
entry.summary:
Two cruise lines suspended visits to Tunisia on Thursday after 17 passengers from their ships were killed in the museum attack, delivering an immediate economic blow to the North African country.

On Thursday morning, both the MSC Splendida and Costa's Fascinosa ship left Tunisia with their remaining passengers, bound for Barcelona and Palma de Mallorca, respectively.

entry.title: 17 foreign tourists killed in Tunisia were cruise passengers
entry.summary: MSC chairman Pierfrancesco Vago said the company hoped to return to Tunisia, but that for now tourists view it as a "no-go zone."

entry.title: Islamic State group claims Tunisia attack that killed 23
entry.summary:
The Islamic State group issued a statement Thursday claiming responsibility for the deadly attack on Tunisia's national museum that killed 23 people, mostly tourists.

Spanish tourist Cristina Rubio, who is four months pregnant, rests at the maternity ward of the Charles Nicolle hospital in Tunis, Tunisia, Thursday March 19, 2015.

A woman cries as she demonstrates in front of the National Bardo Museum a day after gunmen attacked the museum and killed scores of people in Tunis, Tunisia, Thursday, March 19, 2015.

entry.title: Islamic State says it killed tourists in Tunisia
entry.summary:
The assault -- the most deadly attack involving foreigners in Tunisia since a 2002 suicide bombing in Djerba -- came at a fragile moment for a country just emerging to full democracy after its pioneering popular uprising four years ago.

Islamic State, which has declared a caliphate in large parts of Iraq and Syria and is active in Tunisia's chaotic neighbor Libya, praised the two attackers in an audio recording as "knights of the Islamic State" armed with machineguns and bombs.

"We tell the apostates who sit on the chest of Muslim Tunisia: Wait for the glad tidings of what will harm you, o impure ones, for what you have seen today is the first drop of the rain," the Islamic State audio said in Arabic.

entry.title: Islamic State find allies among Tunisia militants
entry.summary: In the wake of the revolution, men with beards were suddenly everywhere in Tunisia as the fall of the secular dictator emboldened extremely pious Muslims known as Salafis to begin preaching across the country.

entry.title: Tunisia Hospitable to Islamic State Recruiting
entry.summary:
The largest group was known as Ansar al-Shariah movement and in a bold showing of strength in 2012, some 4,000 group members of the movement gathered in Kairouan, Tunisia, one of Islam's most revered cities.

In Tunisia, Ansar al-Shariah has since gone underground and its diffuse networks of support are believed to be behind isolated attacks over the years, including failed suicide bombings in October 2013 at Tunisian tourist sites.

entry.summary: A unidentified relative of a victim of the attack, centre, is escorted at the morgue of the Charles Nicolle hospital in Tunis Tunisia, Thursday, March 19, 2015.

entry.title: Tunisia gunmen known to authorities; 2 Spaniards hid all night in fear
entry.summary: TUNIS, Tunisia - One of the gunmen who killed tourists and others at a prominent Tunisian museum was known to the intelligence services but no formal links to a particular extremist group have been established, the prime minister said Thursday.

entry.title: Poland sends doctors to help Poles hurt in Tunisia
entry.summary: Poland sent a plane with doctors and diplomats to Tunisia on Thursday to help and bring back Poles injured in a gun attack in a museum in Tunis.

entry.title: Japan confirms deaths of 3 nationals in Tunisia attack
Japan says three nationals killed, three injured in Tunisia museum attack
entry.summary: Three Japanese were killed, and three others injured, in the militant attack on tourists in Tunisia, the Japanese government said Thursday.

entry.title: 17 tourists killed as gunmen attack Tunisia museum
entry.summary: Tunis (AFP) - Gunmen stormed Tunisia's national museum, killing 17 tourists of various nationalities and two Tunisians in an attack that raised fears for the birthplace of the Arab Spring.

entry.title: Unrest in Tunisia since the popular revolt
entry.summary: Tunis (AFP) - Tunisia on Wednesday saw its first deadly attack on foreigners since the 2010-2011 uprising that toppled president Zine El Abidine Ben Ali after 23 years in power.

entry.title: Timeline of unrest in Tunisia since the popular revolt
entry.summary: December 21: Essebsi wins Tunisia's first free presidential election.

entry.title: 'Our hearts are black': Tunisians in shock after gunmen target tourists in capital
entry.summary: The US secretary of state, John Kerry, said Washington condemned the attack and continued "to support the Tunisian government's efforts to advance a secure, prosperous, and democratic Tunisia".

entry.title: The Latest: Expert: IS applauds Tunisia attack on Twitter
entry.summary: Poland's prime minister has revealed that some of the Polish victims of Tunisia's museum attack were on a tour bus in front of the building when the gunmen opened fire.

entry.title: TUNISIA GUNMEN CAPTURED: Third possibly at large after deadly attack
entry.summary: "We extend our deepest sympathies to the victims of today's heinous violence in Tunisia and condemn in the strongest terms this terrorist attack, which took the lives of innocent Tunisians as well as visiting tourists," Earnest said.

entry.title: The Latest: Expert: IS applauds Tunisia attack on Twitter
entry.summary:
The U.N. Security Council has condemned the Bardo museum attack saying that no terrorist action can reverse the path of Tunisia toward democracy.

The United States, the United Nations, France and the UAE are among the nations condemning the attack on a top museum in Tunisia that left 22 people dead, including 17 tourists and 2 gunmen.

entry.title: The Latest: 21 killed in Tunisia attack; 2-3 gunmen at large
entry.summary:
He extended his condolences to the families of the victims and expressed his solidarity with Tunisia.

The attack was the worst in years on a tourist site in Tunisia, which is struggling to solidify its young democracy and prevent violence by Islamic extremists.

Gunmen opened fire at a leading museum in Tunisia's capital, killing at least eight people and wounding six, including foreign tourists, authorities said.

Tourists and visitors from the Bardo museum are evacuated in Tunis, Wednesday, March 18, 2015 in Tunis, Tunisia.

entry.title: The Latest: 21 killed in Tunisia attack; 2-3 gunmen at large
entry.summary:
The office of French President Francois Hollande has issued a statement mourning the victims of attack at Tunisia's Bardo Museum.

Tunisia's prime minister says a total of 21 people have died in the attack against the Bardo museum, including 17 tourists, two Tunisians and two gunmen.

entry.title: At least 8 dead in Tunisia attack on leading museum
entry.summary:
It was the worst attack in the country since an al-Qaida militant detonated a truck bomb in front of a historic synagogue on the Tunisia's island of Djerba in 2002, killing 21, mostly German tourists.

The attack came the day after Tunisian security officials confirmed the death in neighboring Libya of Ahmed Rouissi, leading suspect in Tunisian terror attacks and in the killings of two opposition figures in Tunisia.

entry.title: Shooting Attack On Tunisia Museum Leaves Several Tourists Dead
entry.summary:
TUNIS, Tunisia (AP) -- Foreign tourists scrambled in panic Wednesday after militants stormed a museum in Tunisia's capital and killed 19 people, "shooting at anything that moved," a witness said.

"I want the people of Tunisia to understand firstly and lastly that we are in a war with terror, and these savage minority groups will not frighten us," said newly elected President Beji Caid Essebsi in an evening address to the nation.

The assault at the Bardo, Tunisia's largest museum that is housed in a 15th century palace, began sometime after noon local time as scores of European tourists were visiting.

entry.title: At least 8 tourists killed, others hostage in Tunisia parliament attack: official
Tunisia says its security forces surround 2 militants inside museum at parliament
Tunisia to reopen airspace for Libyan flights to Tripoli
entry.summary:
TUNIS (Reuters) - Tunisia will reopen part of its airspace to flights from western Libya for the first time in around six months, following the re-establishment of its consulate in Tripoli, a senior official said on Tuesday.

Tunisia decided to reopen its consulate in Tripoli last month.

Tunisia is worried violence will spill over from Libya, where Islamic State militants have expanded their influence, exploiting turmoil as the rival governments fight for control.

entry.title: Tunisia dismantles jihadi recruiting cell for Libya
entry.summary: Tunisia also said on Tuesday it had dismantled a recruiting cell sending jihadis to fight in Libya and arrested dozens in part of tighter security and border controls to counter Islamist militants.

entry.title: 200 Egyptians flee Libya through Tunisia
entry.summary: TUNIS, Tunisia (AP) - A group of almost 200 Egyptians have crossed into Tunisia from Libya, the first of thousands expected to flee the turmoil in the country.
